componenttextpreview: Guitar Center is in the numbers. Yes, I have to -- Greg will get back to you on Citgo.
componenttext: Guitar Center is in the numbers. Yes, I have to -- Greg will get back to you on Citgo.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just -- maybe kind of just more high level. As you think about some of the previous questions, talked a little bit about retailers struggling a little bit, can you talk a little bit how you've become -- how does your relationship with the retailer kin
componenttext: And just -- maybe kind of just more high level. As you think about some of the previous questions, talked a little bit about retailers struggling a little bit, can you talk a little bit how you've become -- how does your relationship with the retailer kind of evolve in that scenario?

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say we have more marketing meetings, for sure. So I think we have retailers who have good and bad times, right? And if you just go back to the crisis, many retailers were struggling, and sales were way down. And I think this is probably the most
componenttext: Yes, I'd say we have more marketing meetings, for sure. So I think we have retailers who have good and bad times, right? And if you just go back to the crisis, many retailers were struggling, and sales were way down. And I think this is probably the most important part of our business model that I think sometimes is not really understood, which is part of our success of keeping relationships for a very long period of time is you really need to stick by the retailer when they're going through that challenge. And what I would say is we have more meetings. We're looking at ways to help them. We're trying to engage more on their strategy. So I would say even at the more senior levels, we're usually talking about, okay, how -- what are you trying to focus on, how can we help you and really drive that kind of engagement. Most of our engagement, particularly at the bigger retailers, are at the CFO, CEO levels. So the card program is such an important part of their sales that we usually just have more engagement on what else can we be doing.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moshe, just to come back on the Citgo question. It'll -- it's in the guidance for 2016, but it's a relatively small portfolio. We think it'll come in the first quarter most likely.
componenttext: Moshe, just to come back on the Citgo question. It'll -- it's in the guidance for 2016, but it's a relatively small portfolio. We think it'll come in the first quarter most likely.

componenttext: Okay. Thanks, everyone, for joining us on the conference call this morning and your interest in Synchrony Financial. The Investor Relations team will be available to answer any further questions you may have. Have a great day.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Synchrony Financial First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Vanessa, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. And I would will now turn the cal
componenttext: Welcome to the Synchrony Financial First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Vanessa, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. And I would will now turn the call over to Greg Ketron, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, operator. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining our call. In addition to today's press release, we have provided a presentation that covers the topics we plan to address during our call. The press release, detailed financial schedules and
componenttext:
Thanks, operator. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining our call. In addition to today's press release, we have provided a presentation that covers the topics we plan to address during our call. The press release, detailed financial schedules and presentation are available on our website, synchronyfinancial.com. This information can be accessed by going to the Investor Relations section of the website. 
Before we get started, I want to remind you that our comments today will include forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainty, and actual results could differ materially. We list the factors that might cause actual results to differ materially in our SEC filings, which are available on our website. 
During the call, we will refer to non-GAAP financial measures in discussing the company's performance. You can find a reconciliation of these measures to GAAP financial measures in our materials for today's call. 
Finally, Synchrony Financial is not responsible for and does not edit nor guarantee the accuracy of our earnings teleconference transcripts provided by third parties. We only offer webcast are located on our website. Margaret Keane, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Brian Doubles, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, will present our results this morning. After we complete the presentation, we will open the call up for questions. 
Now it's my pleasure to turn the call over to Margaret.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. During the call today, I will provide a review of the quarter, and then Brian will give details on our financial results. I'll begin on Slide 3. First quarter net earnings totaled $582 mil
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. During the call today, I will provide a review of the quarter, and then Brian will give details on our financial results. I'll begin on Slide 3. 
First quarter net earnings totaled $582 million or $0.70 per diluted share. Overall, solid momentum continued across each of our business platforms, driving strong double-digit growth in purchase volume, loan receivables and platform revenue this quarter. Compared to the first quarter of last year, purchase volume grew 17% and platform revenue and loan receivables grew 13%. We continue to see strong growth in our online and mobile purchase volume. Our online and mobile sales growth has been steadily accelerating and first quarter sales grew 29% over the same quarter of the prior year. Our online and mobile sales growth has far outpaced U.S. growth trends, which had been in the 14% to 15% range. 
Asset quality metrics were relatively stable this quarter, in line with our expectations. 30-plus-day delinquencies were 3.85% and our net charge-off rate was 4.7% in the range of losses we have experienced in the first quarter over the past 2 years. Expenses were in line with our expectations, increasing 7% over last year. This was largely driven by investments we made in support of our growth initiatives. However, our overall efficiency ratio improved 1.8 percentage points to 30.4%, reflecting our strong revenue growth this quarter. Our receivables growth is supported by continued deposit growth, which grew $10 billion or 29% to $45 billion this quarter. Deposits now comprise 69% of our funding sources at the high end of our targeted range of 60% to 70%. Competitive rates, outstanding customer service and the continued enhancement of our product suite have driven these results, and at this point, you can expect for us to grow a little beyond that original target range. 
One of our strategic priorities is to build Synchrony Bank into a leading full-scale online bank. We plan to launch new product offerings later this year, which will augment growth and enhance the retention of our deposit base. Given the significant growth in deposits, we were able to fully pay off our bank term loan on April 5. We are pleased that we were able to pay off this loan well ahead of its contractual maturity in 2019. 
Our balance sheet remains strong, with a common equity Tier 1 ratio of 18.1%, calculated on a transitional basis and liquid assets totaling $15 billion or 18% of total assets at quarter-end. 
We renewed several key relationships during the quarter, including Stein Mart and La-Z-Boy. We also signed a new partnership with Marvel and recently launched the Marvel MasterCard with an attractive cashback value proposition. We are further leveraging this relationship by developing creative ways to market our deposit products to the Marvel fan base. The new value proposition delivers the greatest benefit on leisure activities including dining out, movies, concerts and amusement parks. Cardholders receive 3% cashback on spending in these types of categories and 1% cashback on other purchases. We are excited about this partnership and the value this new card will bring to loyal Marvel fans and others who enjoy the benefit of a cashback program. The partnership will also offer a unique opportunity to co-promote our deposit products in conjunction with the Marvel feature film. We launched a new campaign called, Save Like a Hero, which will feature Synchrony Bank saving products and be tied to the release of Marvel's new Captain America movie. This is the second starter program we have rolled out in the travel and entertainment space. You'll recall that last quarter, we also launched our Stash Hotel Rewards program. We think this is an area that provides attractive opportunities. 
During the quarter, we also launched our new Citgo card program. Citgo cardholders will be able to earn rewards and save on fuel purchases at any of the 5,000-plus locally owned and operated Citgo locations in the United States. We continue to work with our partners, new and existing, to develop compelling value propositions for their cardholders. 
This quarter, we launched a new value prop with Walmart. The program brings even more value to the everyday purchases customers make using their Walmart cards. The 3-2-1 Save cashback program provides qualifying cardholders the opportunity to earn rewards for purchases they make every day including 3% back on purchases made on walmart.com, 2% back on fuel purchases at Walmart and Murphy USA gas stations and 1% back on purchases made at Walmart stores and everywhere that Walmart cards are accepted. The 3-2-1 Save program simplifies and strengthens the card proposition for Walmart cardholders. We work closely with Walmart to meet the evolving needs of their customers, and we are excited about this program as it also recognizes the increasing move to online and mobile shopping. It is the first credit card program designed to offer Walmart cardholders even greater savings on their online purchases. We are highly focused on innovating ways to drive organic growth as it remains a key priority and opportunity. We continue to work closely with our partners to deliver growth across all sales channels.
Moving to Slide 4, which highlights the performance of our key growth metrics this quarter. Loan receivables growth remains strong at 13%, primarily driven by purchase volume growth of 17% and average asset account growth of 7%. The addition of the BP program in the second quarter of last year also contributed to the annual growth rate. Platform revenue increased 13% over the first quarter of last year. We continue to drive incremental growth through strong value propositions, promotional financing and marketing offers that deliver value to our partners and customers. 
On the next slide, I'll discuss this quarter's performance drivers across our sales platforms. We continue to deliver solid performance across all 3 of our sales platforms in the first quarter. Retail Card generated especially strong results this quarter. Purchase volume growth was 17% and receivables grew 14%. The addition of BP in the second quarter of last year also contributed to the growth rate. Platform revenue growth was 15%. The strong growth in Retail Card was broad-based as we saw growth across our partner programs. 
As I noted earlier, we had an active quarter in Retail Card. We renewed and extended the Stein Mart program. We signed a new partnership with Marvel and launched the new Marvel MasterCard this month, and we launched the new value proposition with Walmart, the 3-2-1 Save cashback program. The position we maintain in this space and the collaborative partnerships we have developed provide a solid foundation for further growth. 
Payment Solutions also delivered another strong quarter. Purchase volume growth was 15% and receivables grew 13%, driving platform revenue growth of 14%. Average active accounts increased 12% over last year. The majority of the industries where we provide financing had positive growth in both purchase volume and receivables, with particular strength in home furnishings and automotive products. We renewed a key home furnishing relationship with the extension of our La-Z-Boy partnership. We continue to expand card use in Payment Solutions, with repeat purchase volume growing 18% year-over-year. Reuse represented 27% of purchase volume in the first quarter. 
CareCredit also delivered a strong quarter. Purchase volume was up 14% and receivables grew 9%, driving platform revenue growth of 6%. Average active accounts increased 7% over last year. Receivables growth this quarter was led by our dental and veterinary specialties. Card reuse continues to be an area of focus in CareCredit, and purchase volume from repeat usage on the card grew 17% compared to last year. Reuse represented 50% of purchase volume in the quarter. 
Our CareCredit digital innovations continue to resonate with cardholders. The CareCredit app has been downloaded more than 350,000 times and visited more than 2.3 million times since we launched it last fall. In addition, our provider locator averaged more than 800,000 hits per month in the first quarter. 
In summary, each platform delivered solid results and continue to make progress in the development, expansion and deepening of important relationships while continuing to drive organic growth. 
I'll now turn the call over to Brian to provide the details on our results.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Margaret. I'll start on Slide 6 of the presentation. In the first quarter, the business earned $582 million of net income, which translates to $0.70 per diluted share in the quarter. This compares to $552 million or $0.66 per diluted share last ye
componenttext:
Thanks, Margaret. I'll start on Slide 6 of the presentation. In the first quarter, the business earned $582 million of net income, which translates to $0.70 per diluted share in the quarter. This compares to $552 million or $0.66 per diluted share last year. We continue to deliver strong growth this quarter with purchase volumes up 17%, receivables up 13% and platform revenue up 13%. Average active accounts increased 7% year-over-year, driven by the strong value propositions on our cards, which continue to resonate with consumers. We also see this in average spend, with purchase volume per average active account increasing 9% over last year as well as growth in average balance per active account up 4% compared to last year. We also closed the BP portfolio acquisition in the second quarter last year, so that helped improve our growth rate year-over-year. 
Net interest income was up 12% in the quarter, mainly driven by the growth in receivables. RSAs were up slightly, $10 million compared to last year. RSAs as a percentage of average receivables were 4.0% for the quarter compared to 4.5% last year. The lower RSA percentage compared to last year is due mainly to higher provision expense associated with growth in the programs as well as higher loyalty cost in our share through the RSA with our retailers. We typically see the RSA decline from the fourth quarter due to lower postholiday-related volume. We still expect the RSA benefit on a full year basis to trend slightly under 4.5%. The provision increased $216 million compared to last year. While the increase was driven by receivables growth, we also had the benefit of a lower reserve build last year due to improved asset quality metrics. I'll cover this in more in detail later.
Asset quality metrics were relatively stable. 30-plus delinquencies were 3.85% compared to 3.79% last year, and the net charge-off rate was 4.70% compared to 4.53% last year. Credit metrics were in line with our expectations and consistent with the range we have seen in the first quarter over the past 2 years. Our allowance for loan losses as a percent of our receivables was 5.5%. Measured against the last 4 quarters' net charge-offs, the reserve coverage is 1.3x, which is consistent with the coverage level over the past 6 quarters. Overall, our reserve coverage metrics were stable. 
Other income decreased $9 million versus last year. Higher loyalty rewards cost were partially offset by an increase in interchange revenue. More specifically, interchange was up $30 million, driven by continued growth in our store spending in our Dual Card. This was offset by loyalty expense that was up $32 million, primarily driven by new value propositions. As a reminder, the interchange and loyalty expense run back through the RSAs, so there's a partial offset on each of these items. 
Debt cancellation fees of $64 million were down $1 million from last year due to the fact that we only offer the product now to our online channel. Other expenses increased $54 million or 7% versus last year, more in line with the growth of the business. Now that we are comparing the periods where the infrastructure build is largely in the run rate, we expect going forward expenses to be driven largely by growth as well as strategic investments in our deposit platform and our digital and mobile capabilities. 
The efficiency ratio for the quarter was 30.4%. The first quarter is typically the low point for the efficiency ratio due to marketing, business development and volume related expenses being at their lowest level for the year. The efficiency ratio will normally increase from these levels in the remainder of the year. I'll cover the expense trends in more detail later. Overall, our strong performance drove a solid quarter generating ROA of 2.8%. 
I'll move to Slide 7 and cover our net interest income and margin trends. As I noted on the prior slide, net interest income was up 12%, driven by strong loan receivables growth. The net interest margin was 15.76% for the quarter, relatively stable to last year in the prior quarter. As you look at the net interest margin compared to last year, there are a few dynamics worth highlighting. The yield on receivables declined 21 basis points to 21.1%, reflecting higher payment rates and a slight mix shift due to the continued strong growth in Payment Solutions, where the yield is lower than our overall portfolio yield. The decline in receivables yield was offset by a slight benefit from rates earn in our liquidity portfolio due to higher short-term benchmark rates resulting from the Fed tightening in December. We also benefited from a higher mix of receivables versus liquidity on average this quarter as we used excess liquidity to pay down the bank term loan facility. 
The cost of funding was relatively stable at 1.9% due to an increase from rising short-term benchmark rates and the cost of the senior unsecured debt issuance, which was largely offset by a higher mix of lower-cost deposit funding, reductions in the bank term loan and the payoff for the GE Capital loan last year. Our deposit base increased by over $10 billion or 29% year-over-year. We're pleased with the progress we made growing our direct deposit platform. Deposits are now 69% of our funding versus 59% last year. While the first quarter margin was a little above the range we set out back in January, this is primarily driven by the benefit of using some excess liquidity to pay down the bank term loans. Overall, we continue to be pleased with our margin performance.
Next, I'll cover our key credit trends on Slide 8. As I noted earlier, we continue to see relatively stable asset quality performance, which was generally in line with our expectations. 30-plus delinquencies were 3.85% versus 3.79% last year and 90-plus delinquencies were 1.84% compared to 1.81% in the prior year. The net charge-off rate was 4.7% compared to 4.53% in the first quarter last year. Both the delinquency metrics and net charge-off levels are consistent with the results in the first quarter of 2014 and 2015. We continue to believe the performance is being sustained due in part by lower gas prices and generally a healthier consumer driven the continued improvement in implement trends. 
Lastly, the allowance for loan losses as a percent of receivables was 5.5%, down slightly from 5.59% last year. As I noted before, if you measure the reserve coverage against the last 12 months' charge-offs, we're currently at 1.3x coverage, which equates to roughly 15.5 months loss coverage in our reserve, which is fairly consistent with prior quarters. So overall, we continue to feel good about the performance of our portfolio and the underlying economic trends we're seeing.
Moving to Slide 9, I'll cover our expenses for the quarter. Overall, expenses continue to be in line with our expectations. Expenses came in at $800 million for the quarter, a 7% increase over last year and are primarily driven by growth of the business and IT investments related to our digital and mobile capabilities. 
Looking at the individual expense categories. Employee costs were up $41 million as we have added employees over the past year in key areas to support the infrastructure build for separation as well as growth of the business. Professional fees were down $16 million, driven primarily by lower third-party spend as a result of our completion of the separation from GE. Marketing and business development costs were up $12 million. The higher costs were driven by increases in portfolio marketing campaigns and promotional offers, which helped drive the strong growth in purchase volume receivables. Information processing was up $19 million, driven by continued IT investments and the increase in transactions and purchase volume compared to last year. As I noted earlier, the efficiency ratio was 30.4% for the quarter due to seasonal low points in marketing, business development and volume-related expenses. We expect the ratio to trend up from this level during the remainder of the year. However, we expect it to remain below 34% in line with what we communicated back in January. 
Moving to Slide 10, I'll cover our funding sources, capital and liquidity position. Looking at our funding profile first. One of the primary drivers of our funding strategy has been the continued strong growth of our deposit base. We continue to view this as a stable, attractive source of funding for the business. Over the last year, we've grown our deposits by over $10 billion primarily for our direct deposit program. This puts deposits at 69% of our funding, which is near the top end of our target range of being 60% to 70% deposit-funded. And while we have now move further towards the top end of our target leverage, we expect to continue to drive growth in our direct deposit program by continuing to offer attractive rates and great customer service as well as building out our digital and mobile capabilities. We are also looking at additional ways to increase the stickiness of this deposit base including the rollout of new products later this year such as checking and online bill pay. Given we are near the top end of our range and we expect to continue to drive deposit growth, we would expect deposits to move a little above 70% of our funding in the upcoming quarters. Longer term, once we reach our optimal mix of deposits, we would expect to grow deposits more in line with our receivable growth. 
Funding through our securitization facilities has been fairly stable in the $12 billion to $14 billion explained and is now 19% of our funding. In March, we successfully issued $750 million in 3-year notes. This is consistent with our approach to maintain securitization of between 15% to 20% of our total funding. Our third-party debt, bank term loan and senior unsecured notes now total 12% of our funding sources. As we said in the past, our strategy was to reduce our reliance on the bank term loan facility as this would become a more expensive source of funding for the business as rates start to rise. Given the significant growth in deposits, we made $2.7 billion of prepayments in the quarter and paid off the remaining $1.5 billion in early April. We are pleased to have fully paid this loan up well ahead of its contractual maturity in 2019. Overall, we feel very good about our access to a diverse set of funding sources.
Turning to capital and liquidity. We ended the quarter at 18.1%, CET1 under the Basel III transition rules and 17.5% CET1 under the fully phased-in Basel III rules. This compares to 16.4% on a fully phased-in basis last year, an increase of 110 basis points over the past year. Total liquidity increased to $22.2 billion and includes $14.9 billion in cash and short-term treasuries and an additional $7.3 billion undrawn securitization capacity. This gives us total available liquidity equal to 27% of our total assets. We expect to be subject to the modified LCR approach and these liquidity levels put us well above the required LCR levels. 
I'd also like to provide an update on our capital plan. Our plan was reviewed and approved by our Board of Directors in late March and we submitted the plan to the Fed in early April. This is in line with the time line we've communicated on previous calls. 
Overall, we're executing on the strategy that we outlined previously. We've built a very strong balance sheet with diversified funding sources and strong capital and liquidity levels. And with that, I'll turn it back over to Margaret.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brian. I'll close with a summary of the quarter on Slide 11 and then we will begin the Q&A portion of the call. During the quarter, we exhibited broad-based growth across key areas, signed and renewed important partnerships and expanded our networ
componenttext:
Thanks, Brian. I'll close with a summary of the quarter on Slide 11 and then we will begin the Q&A portion of the call. During the quarter, we exhibited broad-based growth across key areas, signed and renewed important partnerships and expanded our network in the utility of our cards and continued to develop innovative solutions and value propositions to help drive sales. And our pipeline of additional opportunities remains strong. Our digital channels remain a key component of our overall strategy and we delivered strong growth both online and through our native app. We are pleased with the ongoing success of our fast-growing deposit platforms and strong balance sheet. 
I'll now turn the call back to Greg to open up the Q&A.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Margaret. That concludes our comments on the quarter. Operator, we're now ready to begin the Q&A session.
componenttext: Thanks, Margaret. That concludes our comments on the quarter. Operator, we're now ready to begin the Q&A session.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Ryan Nash with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Ryan Nash with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe we could start with your expectations for credit. First, we did see charge-offs up slightly year-on-year but yet still down from 2014 levels. And I was wondering, is there any change to your, call it, relatively stable 4 30 to 4 50 guidance? And if
componenttext: Maybe we could start with your expectations for credit. First, we did see charge-offs up slightly year-on-year but yet still down from 2014 levels. And I was wondering, is there any change to your, call it, relatively stable 4 30 to 4 50 guidance? And if not -- and if so, how do we think about the trajectory of both provisions and charge-offs over the next few quarters?

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Ryan. So I think it still feels like we're operating in a pretty stable environment when it comes to credit. We continue to think that losses will be stable for the balance of the year. We've been pretty clear that we don't expect them to get b
componenttext: Yes, sure, Ryan. So I think it still feels like we're operating in a pretty stable environment when it comes to credit. We continue to think that losses will be stable for the balance of the year. We've been pretty clear that we don't expect them to get better from here. I think that's pretty consistent across the industry. If you look at the performance in the quarter, it was largely in line with our expectations. If you look at the year-over-year comparison, you have to remember that we had a really strong first quarter last year, which was -- frankly, is better than we expected. We only had a $19 [ph] million reserve build in the first quarter last year. So really what you're seeing now is more of a normalization and generally more in line with our expectations. So if you look at reserve coverage levels, they are also very consistent. Reserve coverage as a percent of our receivables was 5.5%. It was down just 9 basis points from last year. If you look at the reserve coverage against last 12 months' charge-offs, it was 1.29x versus 1.26x a year ago, so also very consistent. So I think for the balance of the year, we continue to see our losses will be stable, an overall change to that 2-year kind of average that we gave in January.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And maybe I can ask a question, Margaret, the outlook for growth, both loan growth and the pipeline for new business wins. Maybe on loan growth, can you talk about how we should think about it from here, how much of the growth is coming from impro
componenttext: Got it. And maybe I can ask a question, Margaret, the outlook for growth, both loan growth and the pipeline for new business wins. Maybe on loan growth, can you talk about how we should think about it from here, how much of the growth is coming from improving penetration rates versus new client wins? You highlighted a couple of times that the year-over-year growth with BP would subside next quarter, so I just want to think -- understand how to think about loan growth. And then the portfolio pipeline for new deals, can you maybe talk about potential startups and maybe any other portfolio deals that you're looking at.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think we've said in the past that we do have BP in the numbers, so that's a little bit of the growth. But the real growth is coming from organic growth and increased penetration. And throughout CareCredit 50% of the sales are repeat. And Payment S
componenttext: Sure. I think we've said in the past that we do have BP in the numbers, so that's a little bit of the growth. But the real growth is coming from organic growth and increased penetration. And throughout CareCredit 50% of the sales are repeat. And Payment Solutions, we're seeing nice repeat I think one of the key drivers of our results is really 2 things. One is the value props that we continue to enhance and drive into our retailers, and we work closely with them to really develop those value propositions. And going back to our financing about the consumer being stable in credit, I do think consumers continue to look for a reason to shop. So having very strong value propositions is really key. The second is really all the innovation we continue to do on mobile. Our online sales overall were up 29% year-over-year in the quarter, which is really a testament to the ability to apply and buy I think. And you combine that with the strong value propositions. I think this is why you're really seeing the kind of growth you're seeing. So I'd say most of it is through existing cardholders who are deepening their loyalty to the brand of that particular retailer. On the pipeline itself, our pipeline continues to remain robust. It's really a mix, I'd say, of startups as well as existing portfolios that we're looking to win. It's a combination of both. We have, as I said in the past, dedicated resources in all 3 platforms. We're working on our network, so in CareCredit being able to add RiteAid, things like that. So very focused on the front end on winning the deals and feeling we have a good pipeline going forward.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just as a very, very quick follow-up, have you disclosed what percentage of overall sales are mobile and online? I'm trying to get a sense for how fast that could grow in the next few years.
componenttext: Just as a very, very quick follow-up, have you disclosed what percentage of overall sales are mobile and online? I'm trying to get a sense for how fast that could grow in the next few years.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we just do the combined digital, which is the 29%. And again, the bulk of the sales are still in-store, obviously, because that's the bulk of where people just continue to shop, but this metric continues to excel. And probably one of the cases is whe
componenttext: Yes, we just do the combined digital, which is the 29%. And again, the bulk of the sales are still in-store, obviously, because that's the bulk of where people just continue to shop, but this metric continues to excel. And probably one of the cases is when we see a consumer shop multichannel, we definitely get higher penetration on the cards. So if they shop in-store and online, for example, we know they're more loyal and intend to stay longer with us. So really working through all those channels is very important.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Hecht with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Hecht with Jefferies.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys provided a lot of your factors with respect to growth in the debt. But I'm wondering, can you talk about active account growth and average spend level trends and how these compared to recent quarters?
componenttext: You guys provided a lot of your factors with respect to growth in the debt. But I'm wondering, can you talk about active account growth and average spend level trends and how these compared to recent quarters?

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, John. So I would say the trends have picked up a little bit from recent quarters primarily around active account growth. So the big thing for us relative to general purpose cards, we're always measuring active account, and that obviously includ
componenttext: Yes, sure, John. So I would say the trends have picked up a little bit from recent quarters primarily around active account growth. So the big thing for us relative to general purpose cards, we're always measuring active account, and that obviously includes new accounts. Active accounts are more important for us because we're trying to create those incentives for cardholders to use the card more often. We want to create value propositions that push our card more towards the top of wallet. And so if you look at purchase volume growth, about half of that came from higher spend per active account. That was up about 8.5% from the prior year, and then the other half came from an increase in overall active accounts, up 7.5%. So a lot of what we're doing around the value proposition is getting -- we're getting consumers to use the card more often and they're also spending more on the card when they use it. So I think all those trends are moving -- continue to move in the right direction, but they did get incrementally better this quarter from where we've been trending.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you talked about the RSA and the seasonality and so forth. Is it -- in thinking about the seasonality going forward, should we just think it kind of moves up so it ends up in the range of the guidance throughout the year? And the second question with
componenttext: And you talked about the RSA and the seasonality and so forth. Is it -- in thinking about the seasonality going forward, should we just think it kind of moves up so it ends up in the range of the guidance throughout the year? And the second question with respect to the RSA business, did the 3-2-1 program at Walmart impact that at all?

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so let's take the first one. The RSA will typically be fairly stable in the first half of the year. As I mentioned, just given we had a very small reserve build last year, and when that happens, our partners benefit from. So if you compare against la
componenttext: Yes, so let's take the first one. The RSA will typically be fairly stable in the first half of the year. As I mentioned, just given we had a very small reserve build last year, and when that happens, our partners benefit from. So if you compare against last year, we had a higher RSA percentage last year than what you saw. The RSA this quarter is actually probably more in line with what you should expect going forward. It's pretty stable in the second quarter. And then we only see a seasonal increase in the RSA percentage in the third quarter it comes down a bit in the fourth quarter, but it is typically elevated in the second half of the year. And then your second question on Walmart, you will see -- depending on how that plays out, it's still very early, but you will see any time we launch a value proposition, you typically see what loyalty cost, interchange will increase and there's a partial offset on the RSA for those items. But I would continue to use slightly below 4.5% range for the year that we gave you.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Sanjay Sakhrani with KBW.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Sanjay Sakhrani with KBW.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, I know it's the first quarter, but the NIM is trending better than your guidance. Is it fair to say that there's some upside given that trend? Similar question for the efficiency ratio. I'm understanding the seasonality, but can we hold kind of the
componenttext: Brian, I know it's the first quarter, but the NIM is trending better than your guidance. Is it fair to say that there's some upside given that trend? Similar question for the efficiency ratio. I'm understanding the seasonality, but can we hold kind of the year-over-year increase in that ratio?

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me just take NIM first. It was slightly above the 15.5% outlook due to the fact that we had really strong deposit growth. We did use some excess liquidity to pay down the bank term loan. So when you look at the average liquidity in the quarter
componenttext: Yes. So let me just take NIM first. It was slightly above the 15.5% outlook due to the fact that we had really strong deposit growth. We did use some excess liquidity to pay down the bank term loan. So when you look at the average liquidity in the quarter compared to last year, it's a little bit lower. So those are all positives some of those were factored in the guidance we gave you and some of them came in a little bit better. I think as you think about the rest of the year, if deposit growth continues at this pace, we could see some benefit there on our margins. We're always looking at ways to optimize liquidity, so there could be a slight benefit there. However, there probably would be a couple of offsets. One is a we continue to see really strong growth in Payment Solutions. You saw that this quarter, and so you'll see a little bit of an offset in our receivable yields. And then our guidance did include, if you remember, it included 50 basis points of Fed rate increases in the back half of the year, and we had those in June and December and so the markets pricing and maybe one rate increase. So that would be just a little bit of pressure on the guidance. So I think some put and takes, I wouldn't think the margin for the balance of the year trending to significantly in either direction from the 15 to 76 we reported this quarter.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Efficiency ratio?
componenttext: Efficiency ratio?

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean on the efficiency ratio, obviously very strong in the quarter, 30.4%. It's definitely going to trend up from here. There's no question. We benefited from having very strong revenue growth in the quarter. We didn't spend a lot on marketing and
componenttext: Yes, I mean on the efficiency ratio, obviously very strong in the quarter, 30.4%. It's definitely going to trend up from here. There's no question. We benefited from having very strong revenue growth in the quarter. We didn't spend a lot on marketing and strategic investments. Those typically accelerate throughout the balance of the year. I'm not going to give you any more specific guidance, and we feel really good particularly how we started the year that we'll stay below the annual guidance of below 34%. So I think that is -- that's definitely a good number. We're really pleased with how we started the year, but I'm not going to give any more specifics than what we said back in January.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Just one final question for Margaret. I guess one of the concerns that I heard during the quarter, and just a follow-up on one of the questions asked before, was that Walmart program and possibly kind of the rising costs to issuers as it relates t
componenttext: Got it. Just one final question for Margaret. I guess one of the concerns that I heard during the quarter, and just a follow-up on one of the questions asked before, was that Walmart program and possibly kind of the rising costs to issuers as it relates to enhanced rewards. I mean could you just talk about how you guys think of the that? I understand it's a share between the merchants as well, but maybe you could just articulate kind of what you guys are thinking in terms of strategy.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure first of all I think we're always looking at ways to enhance value props, right, because the ultimate goal for both us and the partners to grow the program. And if we grow the program through sales and receivables, we all win. So that's kind of a fun
componenttext: Sure first of all I think we're always looking at ways to enhance value props, right, because the ultimate goal for both us and the partners to grow the program. And if we grow the program through sales and receivables, we all win. So that's kind of a fundamental. Remember, whenever we do a launch like this, obviously, we work closely with a partner. And in terms of the overall economics, there's economics in these deals that we can move around, and Frank can talk a little more specifically about that if you want. So for us, the more we grow the program and the more we drive loyalty in the cards through those value proposition, the better we are off as well as the partners. We're pretty excited with this particular launch because it's a program that I think aligns very close to the strategic direction of Walmart, where they really want to drive online sales. So for us, this is a program that is a big launch and one we're excited about, one that I think we can grow the overall program. And when you grow the overall program, we all win. I don't know, Brian, if you'd add more on the economics.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the only thing, I know you guys get this, but the cost of these value proposition run to the RSA, so the partner is sharing in the cost [indiscernible] to drive growth in the program. And then the other thing the we don't talk a lot about but we also
componenttext: Yes, the only thing, I know you guys get this, but the cost of these value proposition run to the RSA, so the partner is sharing in the cost [indiscernible] to drive growth in the program. And then the other thing the we don't talk a lot about but we also set aside marketing and loyalty dollars in the programs, and we jointly agreed with the partner in how to spend those dollars. So we can always reallocated from the marketing funds and maybe we'll choose to do last one of promotion and shift from dollars into everyday value prop. I think this is a really good example where we leverage our data analytics capabilities and we look at spending trends and customer insights to really determine the best way to use those marketing dollars to drive growth.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple of questions, one on the deposit side. You indicated that you have your goals on deposit funding. Just wondering how close you believe you are to that, and what would keep you from wanting to increase deposit to the percentage of total funding
componenttext: So a couple of questions, one on the deposit side. You indicated that you have your goals on deposit funding. Just wondering how close you believe you are to that, and what would keep you from wanting to increase deposit to the percentage of total funding from here.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Betsy. So we obviously continue to have really strong deposit growth. We're up $10 billion year-over-year, 29%. It's been fairly consistent over the past few quarters. I think the only new dynamic is that we did see an influent deposits this qu
componenttext: Yes, sure, Betsy. So we obviously continue to have really strong deposit growth. We're up $10 billion year-over-year, 29%. It's been fairly consistent over the past few quarters. I think the only new dynamic is that we did see an influent deposits this quarter when the Fed raised rates. We didn't move our rates, but I think the announcement of a rate hike people to go check what they were earning in traditional savings account and they decided to move some money around, so we did see a benefit from that in the quarter. In terms of the target range. we're at 69% of our total funding. We gave you a range of between 60% to 70%. So we we're at the high end right now. In my earlier comments, I indicated that we're going to continue to grow deposits. We'll probably grow deposits faster than we're growing our receivables, at least based on the market conditions that we see right now. So I would expect that deposit percentage to trend a little above 70% in the next few quarters. And then we're always looking at whether or not we should revisit that target and maybe take it up a little bit, but I think we're going to see how the rest of the year plays out before we do anything there.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and I would think your deposit growth is adding cost funding relative to the other funding mix you got. So you're using the to drive incremental loan growth that is potentially a little more competitive. In other words, you're using the cheaper fund
componenttext: Okay, and I would think your deposit growth is adding cost funding relative to the other funding mix you got. So you're using the to drive incremental loan growth that is potentially a little more competitive. In other words, you're using the cheaper funding cost to drive more loan growth that is maybe a little more skewed towards value to your partners. Is that fair?

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if you think about the loan growth we're driving, it's been pretty consistent. If you just look at the straight receivable yield, it's pretty flat year-over-year. It was down 21 basis points. And that -- again, that's primarily driven by higher paym
componenttext: Well, if you think about the loan growth we're driving, it's been pretty consistent. If you just look at the straight receivable yield, it's pretty flat year-over-year. It was down 21 basis points. And that -- again, that's primarily driven by higher payment rates that we're seeing across a the portfolio and then more growth in Payment Solutions. So I wouldn't attribute really any of it to the competitive environment. If you look at loyalty cost and you really have to look at loyalty cost in conjunction with the RSA and some of the marketing spend, we're going to continue to launch attractive value proposition to drive growth. I wouldn't think about it direct tie-in with deposits. We're kind of -- we look at them separately. We're trying to fund the balance sheet in a very cost effective way and deposits are very cost-effective for us. We're going to continue to drive deposits, and then we're making different decisions when we look at the retail programs and how to drive growth. Our yields should continue to be pretty stable but for the 2 dynamics that I mentioned earlier, really strong growth in Payment Solutions and slightly higher payment rates.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay and the just a follow-up on the credit questions that you got earlier. It sounded to me like the 1Q result in NCS was more seasonal. I know we saw in the master trust data March improved versus February. So my takeaway is that seasonality should driv
componenttext: Okay and the just a follow-up on the credit questions that you got earlier. It sounded to me like the 1Q result in NCS was more seasonal. I know we saw in the master trust data March improved versus February. So my takeaway is that seasonality should drive down NCS as we move into the second and third quarter. I don't know if you would agree with that. Maybe you could speak to the fact that delinquencies seas have been coming down in the 30- and 90-day buckets and what the implications are kind of forward look from your perspective.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you remember back in January, we tried to be pretty clear that we didn't expect the favorability we saw kind of in the first half of 2015 to continue when we gave you how to think about the provision. If you look at -- so if you look at the net ch
componenttext: Yes. If you remember back in January, we tried to be pretty clear that we didn't expect the favorability we saw kind of in the first half of 2015 to continue when we gave you how to think about the provision. If you look at -- so if you look at the net charge-offs in the quarter and you just to go back, in the first quarter of 2014, net charge-offs were 4.86%. In the first quarter of 2015, they were 4.53% and we're at 4.7% this quarter. So smack down in the middle of that range that we gave you back in January. so I think that was pretty good guidance and we came in right in line with our expectations and that's why we gave you a range for the year. We said credit will be stable, but it will be stable to like a 2-year range in that 4.3% to 4.5% kind of level. And reserves will grow in line with receivables, and that's absolutely what we saw this quarter and you're seeing very stable reserve coverage metrics.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Moshe Orenbuch with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Moshe Orenbuch with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, you talked about the breakdown of kind of existing accounts versus kind of new accounts for spending. I guess maybe to be a little bit more basic, the 17% obviously benefited this quarter by the leap year and there might have been some [indiscernib
componenttext: Brian, you talked about the breakdown of kind of existing accounts versus kind of new accounts for spending. I guess maybe to be a little bit more basic, the 17% obviously benefited this quarter by the leap year and there might have been some [indiscernible] things a year ago. What do you think the underlying actual growth rate is and maybe talk a little bit about your share at retailers and how that's moving.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So if you adjust for day count, purchase volume were moved from 17% to 15% growth. Year-over-year, platform revenue were moved from 13% to 12%. That's the impact I think. Even adjusting for day count, we had really strong growth in the quarter.
componenttext: Yes, sure. So if you adjust for day count, purchase volume were moved from 17% to 15% growth. Year-over-year, platform revenue were moved from 13% to 12%. That's the impact I think. Even adjusting for day count, we had really strong growth in the quarter. The purchase volume per average active was up, so consumer spending more average balance per active account was up as well. So we still think they will revolve on the accounts, overall, very positive trends. I think the thing to think about as you try and figure out the back half of the year, starting in the second quarter, the comps will get a little bit tougher for us. We've got the BP portfolio, the tire center, we also the Amazon 5% value prop. You got to factor those in as we think about the second half of the year, but we're really pleased with how we started. We didn't get a ton of help from retail sales. They were pretty much more the same of what we've been seeing. So we're definitely taking share. We definitely outperforming. If you look at the total credit card balances over the past 5 years, it's about $900 billion of balances and they've been growing at about 3%. Our growth over that same time period is 9%, and so there's no question that we're taking share in the market.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, and you had mentioned Citgo. Are there other programs that are going to be kind of ramping in the second half?
componenttext: Great, and you had mentioned Citgo. Are there other programs that are going to be kind of ramping in the second half?

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think that's the one and again it's a relatively modest deal. We'll have probably a tougher comp from BP and Guitar Center. Citgo won't totally offset that. So the comp will get tougher but the core organic growth is really strong. We obviously hope
componenttext: No. I think that's the one and again it's a relatively modest deal. We'll have probably a tougher comp from BP and Guitar Center. Citgo won't totally offset that. So the comp will get tougher but the core organic growth is really strong. We obviously hope to have some program wins in the back half of the year and we'll announce those when we get them done.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe from a big picture perspective, you talked a little bit about the Walmart program and the sharing of the RSA. So maybe you could just talk philosophically about that kind of a relationship versus program relationship with how it might be different i
componenttext: Maybe from a big picture perspective, you talked a little bit about the Walmart program and the sharing of the RSA. So maybe you could just talk philosophically about that kind of a relationship versus program relationship with how it might be different in addition to just your share in RSA.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think probably the key thing or the difference between the program in the pure Walmart example is really the engagement that you really get at the top. And I think in all of our big programs, the most important thing is for us to really connect wit
componenttext: Yes, I think probably the key thing or the difference between the program in the pure Walmart example is really the engagement that you really get at the top. And I think in all of our big programs, the most important thing is for us to really connect with the strategy that, that particular retailer or partner is really trying to drive. And so the engagement both from an analytics and marketing perspective is just so high. You don't necessarily always get that same connection when you're doing the [indiscernible] so I think that makes a big difference. I think the other thing that all retailers are really facing is how do they reach out to their target markets. And I think the fact that we had this 29% online growth overall year-over-year is certainly a way for us to really continue to connect with the partners because the reality is consumers are shopping differently. So I think really be engaged at the strategy level with the retailers is probably one of the, I think, bigger differences between what we're doing on that side versus generic cobrand.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Bill Carcache with Nomura.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Bill Carcache with Nomura.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a follow-up question, Brian, on the seasonality that you talked about on Slide 8. So it looks like the allowance, the reserve rates essentially peaks in the first quarter, and we saw that in '15 and that you kind of gradually decreases again before
componenttext: I had a follow-up question, Brian, on the seasonality that you talked about on Slide 8. So it looks like the allowance, the reserve rates essentially peaks in the first quarter, and we saw that in '15 and that you kind of gradually decreases again before peaking in the next quarter of the next year. And as we've been looking at year-over-year trends, that reserve rate has actually been following every single one of the periods that are shown here. And similarly, first quarter '16 fell over first quarter '15. But at some point, should we expect the year-over-year to reflect an increase similar to kind of what the charge-off rates up above we have been seeing year-over-year declines. Now this quarter we saw year-over-year increase. When should we for modeling purposes expect that to happen for the reserve rate as well?

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you go back to what we said in January, we're pretty much indicated that we thought the coverage metrics would be stable. So if you go back and compared against the prior year, we're seeing that stability. So even though we saw 9 basis points of i
componenttext: Yes. If you go back to what we said in January, we're pretty much indicated that we thought the coverage metrics would be stable. So if you go back and compared against the prior year, we're seeing that stability. So even though we saw 9 basis points of improvement or I guess the lowering of the reserve coverage from the first quarter '15 to the first quarter '16, from our perspective, that's like dead stable. That's very consistent. And so I think you're going to start to see that normalization as you go and compare the prior quarter from the prior year. So I think you're seeing it now. I would tell you to look at both the reserve coverage as a percent of the receivables as well as look at the reserves as a percent of or against last 12 months in net charge-offs. And if you triangulate those 2, we think they'll be pretty stable for the balance of the year.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I may, an industry level question for you, Margaret. So there's been, I guess, a lot of focus on the friction in the payment ecosystem that certain players like people have created by getting customers to fund their PayPal accounts with their bank
componenttext: And if I may, an industry level question for you, Margaret. So there's been, I guess, a lot of focus on the friction in the payment ecosystem that certain players like people have created by getting customers to fund their PayPal accounts with their bank accounts effectively disintermediating Visa and MasterCard and their issuing bank partners. And if you extend that thought process, part of the Synchrony value proposition to its retail partners is not charging interchange on their private label transactions. And in a sense, one could argue that private label is effectively disintermediating general purpose cards, but there doesn't -- and of course, we've seen some private label market share gains over the last decade or so. But there doesn't seem to be as much friction between Synchrony and Visa MasterCard and their issuing bank partners. So I was hoping maybe you could just speak to the help of your relationship with the payment networks and then maybe also just touch on some of those dynamics.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think we're working very closely with all those guys. I think at the end of the day, how a consumer is going to decide how they make their payment is going to be up to them, right? SO I think the position we've taken is that all of the players tha
componenttext: Sure. I think we're working very closely with all those guys. I think at the end of the day, how a consumer is going to decide how they make their payment is going to be up to them, right? SO I think the position we've taken is that all of the players that you talked about are really partners of ours including PayPal, by the way, where we offer credit program. So for us, it's really about getting our cards in that wall, whatever wall it is, to be top of wall and to get consumer to use it more. I think the connection we have with merchants I think it's very different than many of the players out there. And I think that's the value we bring even to some of the partners you talked about, like Visa or MasterCard and PayPal, right? So we have that very tight connection with the merchant. And so we see this all as upside for us and continue to see that whole payment landscape as an opportunity for us to be in the forefront and continue to invest, and we'll continue to invest to be leaders in that.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from David Ho with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from David Ho with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just circling back on the credit. Margaret, have w3e seen some -- within the industry some pressure, some merchants, retailers to basically increase their -- the funnel, widen that out a little bit to drive volumes, and may be a little pickup on non-prime
componenttext: Just circling back on the credit. Margaret, have w3e seen some -- within the industry some pressure, some merchants, retailers to basically increase their -- the funnel, widen that out a little bit to drive volumes, and may be a little pickup on non-prime credit duration for those customers down in the lower FICO spectrums. Can you remind us how you guys tend to offset this with existing partners or with new RFPs with de novo? And are you seeing that pressure to be a little looser on credit?

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not seeing that. Our partners are not asking us to go deeper. I think we've been very consistent since the crisis in our underwriting. We have not changed underwriting. Our portfolio has remained fairly consistent since 2011. So I think this is wher
componenttext: We're not seeing that. Our partners are not asking us to go deeper. I think we've been very consistent since the crisis in our underwriting. We have not changed underwriting. Our portfolio has remained fairly consistent since 2011. So I think this is where the goal should be not going necessarily deeper but ensuring that you're bringing the value and sales in a way through marketing through being innovative through driving channel integration and really working in that way. We control underwriting. It's something that we feel we have to do when we to our contracts. So that's something that I think is really important from a safety and soundness perspective from our bank. And we work with the retailers. There's many other ways to grow programs without having to necessarily always dig deeper. I don't know, Brian, if you've mentioned really how the portfolio...

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean that underwriting profile is very consistent with where it's been. The average FICO by account is 711, exactly flat to last year. 78% of the new accounts since 2010 are prime credits. It's above [ph] 660 FICO. And then if you look at the total
componenttext: Yes, I mean that underwriting profile is very consistent with where it's been. The average FICO by account is 711, exactly flat to last year. 78% of the new accounts since 2010 are prime credits. It's above [ph] 660 FICO. And then if you look at the total portfolio, 72% of the accounts are prime credits above 660 FICO, and that's flat to last year as well. So the overall credit profile continues to be very stable.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And separately, on Amazon, obviously, you've gotten some really nice digital online growth. Now are you seeing that volume come in as transactors versus revolvers? And the reason I as is obviously is a private label program. So you don't e
componenttext: That's helpful. And separately, on Amazon, obviously, you've gotten some really nice digital online growth. Now are you seeing that volume come in as transactors versus revolvers? And the reason I as is obviously is a private label program. So you don't earn any interchange but you're obviously paying fairly high rewards. So part of that does get offset on the RSA realized but are you getting the revolved activity that you were expecting in that relationship?

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. When we -- obviously, when we launched that new value proposition, we did a lot of modeling initially because we knew that through the door population and people applying for the accounts was going to change. And so that's part of the reason why, if
componenttext: Yes. When we -- obviously, when we launched that new value proposition, we did a lot of modeling initially because we knew that through the door population and people applying for the accounts was going to change. And so that's part of the reason why, if you remember, when we launched it, we launched it with a soft launch because we wanted to monitor the mix of consumers and we wanted to make sure that we were sizing lines appropriately, that it was a good experience for the prime customer that we're generating increment sales for Amazon, so we have a lot of things that we are measuring. But one of the big ones for the credit program was a revolver versus transactors, and we've monitored. It's coming in pretty close to what we forecast. So far, very much in line with our expectations. And obviously, the point you made is a good one which is part of why you see loyalty expense growing a little bit faster than interchange because that's the program where we do have a very attractive value proposition but we don't charge interchange to Amazon. So there is an offset in the RSA. It's all part of that restructuring and that agreement and part of the extension that we do at Amazon when we launched the new value proposition.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And one more follow-up on that if I may. Are you seeing a general trend broadly that merchants are more willing to fund a larger portion of the value from the high rewards earned now that they've seen -- that they've gotten some good engagement and
componenttext: Sure. And one more follow-up on that if I may. Are you seeing a general trend broadly that merchants are more willing to fund a larger portion of the value from the high rewards earned now that they've seen -- that they've gotten some good engagement and account activity.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that varies retail by retail. But I think if you take the whole formula of what we do, the retail is always looking to fund greater loyalty to their brand and their card. And we have retail who take some of the earnings off the RSA and [indiscerni
componenttext: I think that varies retail by retail. But I think if you take the whole formula of what we do, the retail is always looking to fund greater loyalty to their brand and their card. And we have retail who take some of the earnings off the RSA and [indiscernible] right back into additional offers. So it varies across. I think the reality is right now everyone is -- Brian mentioned it early, retailers sales have not been necessarily stellar. SO our retailers and our partners are really looking to us to work with them to really make sure we're continuing to get the right offers out there. But the retailers are high. The more engaged the retailer is, usually the better the program performances.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's not really a new phenomenon. You have to remember, we did low as 5% off a few years back. I think you're seeing more of this now, but it's a mix as well. It's maybe doing a little bit less one-off promotions, doing more on an everyday value prop. Aga
componenttext: It's not really a new phenomenon. You have to remember, we did low as 5% off a few years back. I think you're seeing more of this now, but it's a mix as well. It's maybe doing a little bit less one-off promotions, doing more on an everyday value prop. Again, this is where we're using our data analytics to really determine what is the best value proposition to get the consumer to come in to spend more. And so we're always looking at optimizing that mix between the one-off promotion and the everyday value prop.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark DeVries with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark DeVries with Barclays.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to start with a quick follow-up on Amazon. Are you any closer now to a harder rollout on that program?
componenttext: Just wanted to start with a quick follow-up on Amazon. Are you any closer now to a harder rollout on that program?

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, we're on full rollout now. That really happened over holiday. The marketing around it is targeted marketing, and Amazon controls a lot of that. But the program is performing very well in line with our expectations and we're pleased with the marketin
componenttext: Mark, we're on full rollout now. That really happened over holiday. The marketing around it is targeted marketing, and Amazon controls a lot of that. But the program is performing very well in line with our expectations and we're pleased with the marketing and the advertising around it.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, are you seeing volumes accelerating as a result of that?
componenttext: Okay, are you seeing volumes accelerating as a result of that?

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We continue to see good volumes on the Amazon program. Obviously, can't get real specific around it, but we're really excited when we launched it and it's performing in line with our expectations.
componenttext: We continue to see good volumes on the Amazon program. Obviously, can't get real specific around it, but we're really excited when we launched it and it's performing in line with our expectations.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And I was hoping trying turning to the Walmart 3-2-1, I was hoping if you could comment at least a high level on how your level optimism that, that could really enhance your tender share there because this is a pretty substantial enhancement
componenttext: Okay, great. And I was hoping trying turning to the Walmart 3-2-1, I was hoping if you could comment at least a high level on how your level optimism that, that could really enhance your tender share there because this is a pretty substantial enhancement of the rewards prop relative to the old card, which is pretty modest. We've always. . .

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say that's why we're pretty excited. We've been working with Walmart since 1999 and most of the value prop on the card has been kind of more pulsing promotional types of things like $0.05 or $0.10 off gas or something like that or some of the type
componenttext: I would say that's why we're pretty excited. We've been working with Walmart since 1999 and most of the value prop on the card has been kind of more pulsing promotional types of things like $0.05 or $0.10 off gas or something like that or some of the types of offerings. So to get a consistent value prop, that's -- everyday use is really a big deal because that's when the consistency and the usage of the card goes up. And obviously, Walmart is a big retailer, so we're pretty excited about it.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, fair enough. So given the massive size of them, can you give us some sense of what even a modest increase in tender share can lead to loan growth.
componenttext: Yes, fair enough. So given the massive size of them, can you give us some sense of what even a modest increase in tender share can lead to loan growth.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's hard for us to get specific around an individual program. Mark, you can take a look at what Walmart sales are in the U.S. and you can calculate your own percentage, but Walmart continues to be a significant growth opportunity for us.
componenttext: Well, it's hard for us to get specific around an individual program. Mark, you can take a look at what Walmart sales are in the U.S. and you can calculate your own percentage, but Walmart continues to be a significant growth opportunity for us.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just one last question if I may. Given you're only 1 quarter in but we had 13% loan growth and guidance is for 7% to 9% receivable growth. Does that just feel a little bit conservative here? Even if you take away -- you lap the comps
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just one last question if I may. Given you're only 1 quarter in but we had 13% loan growth and guidance is for 7% to 9% receivable growth. Does that just feel a little bit conservative here? Even if you take away -- you lap the comps on BP Guitar Center, you're still probably 11% or so. You have to see a pretty material slowing in growth of the end of the year just to get to the high-end of the range, and that's what the backdrop some really solid momentum around things like Amazon and Walmart something you could comment on that.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. Obviously, we had a very strong quarter. we're really pleased with the overall growth. The only thing I would point out is the back half the comps get tougher. If the trends continue, we can be a little bit better. We're really pleased, when we
componenttext: Yes, sure. Obviously, we had a very strong quarter. we're really pleased with the overall growth. The only thing I would point out is the back half the comps get tougher. If the trends continue, we can be a little bit better. We're really pleased, when we look across the portfolio, all 3 platforms growing really well. All the underlying dynamics in line are better than what we expected. So we're really pleased with how we started the year. We're not going to update guidance, and now I would just remind you that the comps get a little bit tougher. But as you pointed out, the start of the year has been really strong.

headline: Synchrony Financial, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
